case_name: Madan Gopal v. Deputy Commissioner Bhatinda

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 329 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 329 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 28, 1958 of Punjab High Court in L.P.A. No. 72 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 28, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in L. P. A. No. 72 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 27, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 27. The Judgment of the Court was. delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Appellant Madan Gopal appointed Inspector of Consolidation on October 5, 1953 by Settlement Commissioner of Patiala and East Punjab States Union on temporary basis terminable with one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Madan Gopal was appointed an Inspector of Consolidation by order dated October 5, 1953 of the Settlement Commissioner of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union. The appointment was ,on temporary basis and terminable with one Months numberice.

facts.text: On February 5, 1955, appellant served with charge-sheet by Settlement Officer, Bhatinda alleging receipt of Rs. 150/- illegal gratification from Darbara Singh and demand of Rs. 30/- from Ude Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On February 5, 1955, the appellant was served with a charge-sheet by the Settlement Officer, Bhatinda that he  the appellant  had received Rs. 150/- as illegal gratification from one Darbara Singh and bad demanded Rs. 30/- as illegal gratification from one Ude Singh.

facts.text: Appellant submitted explanation to the charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted his explanation to the charge-sheet.

facts.text: On February 22, 1955, Settlement Officer submitted report to Deputy Commissioner Bhatinda that charge relating to receipt from Darbara Singh was proved.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1955, the Settlement Officer submitted his report to the Deputy Commissioner Bhatinda, that the chage relating to recept of illegal gratification from Darbara Singh was proved.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner ordered termination of Madan Gopal's services forthwith on March 17, 1955 with one month's pay in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner by order dated March 17, 1955 ordered that the services of Madan Gopal Inspector be terminated forthwith and that in lieu of numberice be will get one months pay as required by the Rules.

facts.text: Appellant requested Deputy Commissioner to review the order and submitted memorial to Minister for Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant requested the Deputy Commissioner to review the order, and also submitted a memorial to the Minister for Revenue affairs.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court of Pepsu for writ under Art. 226 quashing March 17, 1955 order on grounds of Art. 311 contravention, no reasonable opportunity, authority of Settlement Officer, irregular procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Having failed to obtain relief, the appellant applied to to the High Court of Pepsu for a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution quashing the order dated March 17, 1965 on theground inter alia that the order of dismissal from service was in companytravention of Art. 311 of the Constitution as numberreasonable opportunity to show-. cause against the order of dismissal was at all given. He also challenged the authority of the Settlement Officer to hold the enquiry and submitted that the procedure followed by that Officer in making the enquiry was irregular.

facts.text: Petition transferred to High Court of Punjab on reorganization of State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was transferred to the High Court of Punjab on the reorganization of the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Bishan Narain issued the writ as termination was punishment and Art. 311(2) not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Bishan Narain who heard the application issued the writ prayed for, because, in his view, the order of termination of employment was in the nature of an order of punishment and an the provisions of Art. 311 2  had number been companyplied with by the Enquiry Officer, the. Deputy Commis- sioner or the Settlement Commissioner, the order was invalid.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court reversed the single judge order holding appellant temporary servant, termination under terms of employment, no penalty imposed.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal under the Letters Patent, the order was reversed by, a Division Bench of the High Court. The High Court held that the appellant was a temporary servant and had numberright to hold the post he was occupying and by the impugned order the appellant was number dismissed or removed from service, but his employment was terminated ,in exercise of authority reserved under the terms of employment, and numberpenalty was imposed upon the appellant,

facts.text: State admitted in High Court written statement that employment terminated on March 17, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: No such order is however found on the record, and it appears that in the written statement filed by the State in the High Court it was expressly admitted that the employment of the appellant was terminated on March 17, 1955.

facts.text: Settlement Officer reported appellant received Rs. 150/- illegal gratification, did not enjoy good reputation, person of doubtful integrity.

anchor.surface_text: The Settlement Officer reported that on the evidence he was satisfied that the appellant had received Rs. 150/- as illegal gratification and that the appellant did number ,enjoy good reputation and was a person of doubtful integrity.

facts.text: Appellant given opportunity to make defence, witnesses examined before Settlement Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was given an opportunity to make his defence and it appears that witnesses in support of the charge and in defence were examined before the Settlement Officer.

facts.text: Counsel for State contended effective order by Settlement Officer on March 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel appearing for the State of Punjab companytended that the order dated March 17, 1955, was number the order pursuant to which employment of the appellant was terminated, the effective order being one passed by the Settlement Officer on March 30, 1955.

facts.text: No order of Settlement Officer on March 30, 1955 found on record.

anchor.surface_text: No such order is however found on the record,

precedents.citation: State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad  1

anchor.surface_text: State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad  1 , the learned Chief Justice in dealing with cases of termination of service or discharge of public servant on probation set out five propositions of which the 3rd is enunciated thus But. if instead of terminating such a persons service without any enquiry, the employer chooses to hold an enquiry into his alleged misconduct, or inefficiency, or for some similar reason, the termination of service is by way of punishment, because it puts a stigma on his companypetence and thus affects his future career.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad
precedents.cited_proposition: if instead of terminating such a persons service without any enquiry, the employer chooses to hold an enquiry into his alleged misconduct, or inefficiency, or for some similar reason, the termination of service is by way of punishment, because it puts a stigma on his competence and thus affects his future career. In such a case, he is entitled to the protection of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution
precedents.cited_holding: 3rd proposition: termination after enquiry into misconduct is punitive

precedents.citation: State of Orissa v. Ram Narayan Das  1

anchor.surface_text: State of Orissa v. Ram Narayan Das  1 . In Ram Narayan Dass case enquiry was made pursuant to Rules governing the conduct of public servants for ascertaining whether the probation of the public servant concerned should be continued and a notice to show cause in that behalf was served upon him. On the report of the enquiry officer that the work and conduct of the public servant as unsatisfactory, an order of termination of employment was passed without affording him an opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v. Ram Narayan Das
precedents.cited_proposition: enquiry pursuant to rules to ascertain whether probation should be continued, followed by termination without further opportunity, is not punitive as no stigma or evil consequences
precedents.cited_holding: An order discharging a probationer following upon an enquiry to ascertain whether he should be confirmed, is not by way of punishment

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra case  1 . In this case the enquiry made by the Settlement Officer was made with the object of ascertaining whether disciplinary action should be taken against the appellant for his alleged misdemeanour. It was clearly an enquiry for the purpose of taking punitive action including dismissal or removal from service if the appellant was found to have committed the misdemeanour charged against him.

precedents.cited_proposition: tests laid down to determine whether an order of termination is by way of punishment

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: It is number well-settled that the protection of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution applies as much to a temporary public A.I.R. 1960 S.C. 689, servant as to permanent public servants. By virtue of Art. 311 of the Constitution the appellant was number liable to be dismissed or removed from service until he had been given reasonable opportunity against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him. The appellant was given numbersuch opportunity and Art. 311 of the Constitution was therefore number companyplied with.

anchor.surface_text: No such order is however found on the record, and it appears that in the written statement filed by the State in the High Court it was expressly admitted that the employment of the appellant was terminated on March 17, 1955.

It is number well-settled that the protection of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution applies as much to a temporary public A.I.R. 1960 S.C. 689, servant as to permanent public servants. By virtue of Art. 311 of the Constitution the appellant was number liable to be dismissed or removed from service until he had been given reasonable opportunity against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him. The appellant was given numbersuch opportunity and Art. 311 of the Constitution was therefore number companyplied with.

Therefore, the fact of the holding of an enquiry is number decisive of the question. What is decisive is whether the order is by way of punishment, in the light of the tests laid down in Parshotam Lal Dhingra case  1 . In this case the enquiry made by the Settlement Officer was made with the object of ascertaining whether disciplinary action should be taken against the appellant for his alleged misdemeanour.
